I first played this game over 2 years ago when it was offered through EA games website.  Until they shut it down because no one was playing it anymore.  I noticed it was offered through steam and I wanted to come back for 2 main reasons.
First, to see if anything had been changed, improved in all that time and the most important one was so when I wrote this review it would be as accurate as possible.  Yes, I did forget about this game and most of the content in 2 years so I wanted to be accurate.

First of all let me give you my recommendation, NO, please do not download or play this game.

For those of you with no patience it is sid meyers sim city meets micro transactions.

The game is a browser game port that requires flash to play.  It is hardwired so that it prefers google chrome flash over adobe flash.  Up to a few days ago if you had a semi modern pc or laptop you could not even get into the game because it did not recognisze a 64 bit flash version as a valid one.  Yes, it was a straight port over from browser to steam.

Okay I will step up on my soap box, I personally do not think browser games or phone games belong on steam period.
Now I will step off of my soap box and tell you why this game, this Anno Online is bad.

Before I do that I want to give 2 points away to those few people who give this a positive review.  It is not pay to win, there  is no PVP at all, barely any combat I will go into that in detail in a bit.  Let us call it what it is, pay to play.  There is someone in the forum who claimed to be able to unlock everything for free but he did spend over 400 days doing it.  I can not confirm or deny it but it does sound about right.  Let me give you a warning here.  If you ever miss one day logging in your loyalty program will drop back to day 1, even if you did spend 2 years playing it.
My second point I will give those few people with a positive review is if you are going to write a review, good or bad please use more then 1 word so it is helpful.  Okay got those out of the way.

Your little ship shows up on a new island, you build your first house and your first woodcutter.  Total population 1, yeah.
Then you will spend the next 8 to 10 hours depending on how familiar you are with sid meyers sim city games to grow your population from 1 pioneer to 1500 vassals. You will make houses, farms, markets and wells, maybe a church here or there.  Then you scratch your head and go, hmmm, now what.

Now you hit the first pay wall.  Your little settlers are asking you to give them linen shirts which takes hemp which your main island does not have.  So now you have 2 choices. I have been a player of this game since Aug of 2013, when the game was only browser based and in beta. when I first started playing there were several bugs, but in the past year (2014) most of the bugs have been cleared, and a lot of new content and changes have happened.  This game is constantly changing and always for the better.

Unlike most Free to play games, Anno Online has NO PVP, which makes for a different environment.  My fellow players and myself have a very helpful community VS one out to kill each other.  Another thing that sets Anno Online apart from the others is that you don't need to buy the ingame currency to get anywhere, all you need is a little amount of time... I didn't hit the top population on the starting island till a year after I started playing, but no other player insulted me, or kicked me out of their guild because i hadn't hit the End Game".

This game could be compared to a mobile city builder game, it is not a game you can play longer than a few minutes to an hour each day, unless you want to spend real money on resources and other stuff to speed things up. You log in, build a little, upgarde some buildings, and once you use up the resources generated over the past 15+ hours you are pretty much done and have to wait a day for your resources and money to replenish to continue.
If you don't have a lot of time and just want to build a little each day Anno Online is a good choice; however if you are after a game you can sit and play for hours at a time building up a huge empire without limitations you are better off with a full Anno game be it 1404 similar to Anno Online in style or 2070 with a futuristic setting.

In my opinion it's better to spend a bit of money up front and buy Anno 1404. You will get a lot more out of it and you don't have to constantly wait for things to finish.

Firstly, let me get the hours i've played out of the way, i haven't used the Steam version at all, i've been playing the browser version for many months, i'm up to 941 imperials, without spending anything. Although i did buy Anno 1404 just to try it out, I actually prefer this game to Anno 1404.

It's the sort of game where you play a little while then come back later. The fact that you can move buildings around to optimize population and farms is one of it's stronger points. There's a scoreboard tab in the quest book which shows population, so you can compete with other players if you want to.

Where it really shines is the quests they give you, simple things but it's fun to mess around with ships and population (more population, more gold).

i personally ignored the ship battle part of the game, you can do that if you want, although you might be one island short at the end, but it doesn't matter. Yes, there are several islands you will be able to build on, and you can swap between them at any time, another good feature.

You can make friends and join guilds, but i never bothered with the guilds. I would have liked to play the Steam version with my old account, but it won't let me.

1) A few tips before you start, don't spend your rubies, keep them to upgrade the Ruby Cutter, costs 2,999 rubies. You get rubies every week and when you increase in level.
2) You can buy wood with gold from the store but it's limited to a certian amount.
3) Do not place the Guildhall down, it is a waste of space, you can't remove it, and you won't need it.

I recommend this game especially if you like the old The Settlers games, where it takes time to do stuff, it's made by the same makers.

reviewText:
So this is what I am going to tell you. I am playing this game for 1 year and more, but I had a stop of something like 6-8 months. But since I returned I keep playing the game. So the game is typical anno- you construct, collect resrouces, trade with other players and if you want, you can make some naval battles.
First things first.
You need patience for this game. It is the same typical time strategy. You wait for minutes or hours for something to be completed.
Sometimes you will progress very slowly and you will even think that you do not progress at all, but sometimes your progress could be fast as a bullet, shot from AK-47.
The economy is typical to the Anno games- for some tools and equipement you will need another one, created from a resource.
You discover new islands but you need to unlock the slot first.
The premium currency are gems. But because I have a building that actually I can make gems, I feel like I do not need to spend a cent for the game. You have daily log-in reward and every 7th day, you get some raw gems that you can transfer to real gems and use them. The city building aspect of the game is extremely addictive, and the simplified naval combat was just getting interesting.  All in all, this game is quite fun, and I would absolutely love to continue to play it.... *If* the User Interface would resize itself properly in the window.  I can't reach certain buttons half the time, because they are partially obscured by the bottoms of the game window, and resizing the window does *nothing.*

The easiest fix for this would simply be to make the game fullscreen, but that doesn't seem to be something the devs were willing to do -- therefore ruining an otherwise wonderful game, IMHO...

If you're willing to put up with partially obscured UIs and visually jarring windowed modes, then by all means, give this game a shot!  It *is* a well-made City Builder, but there are cleaner, better made titles available to choose from out there for reasonable prices.

I have to review this game. Im thinking all the bad review I saw were right after it was released and it had some issues? I absolutely LOVE this game so far and am about 2 hours into it. It has a little bit of banished, and a few pieces of other city builder games that so  far has been wonderful to me.
I have gotten no lag since I started playing, no loading issues, and no errors. Everything has run very smoothly. The buildings and graphics look great to me, very pleasing to the eyes.
With that out of the way I will explain a little on why I like it. You start out with a simple tutorial to show you what you need to know. Build a few houses, and make sure they have water and a market nearby. As you expand you get new items to build and open up new areas of the map/island. You get bonuses when you level up and complete tasks at the left side of your map. I havent seen a need to spend real money yet so far. If you missplace something or want to reorganize your town, theres an easy move tool so you dont need to demolish anything and rebuild it elsewhere.
I think before anyone passes by this game to just sit down for an hour to learn it THEN decide if its for you. I will be continuing to play it. :)

those whi say its a pay to win ?? win what??? there is no winning ... its a city builder and simple pve naval battle game. there are ranking lists though for those who like to compete. like an old fashoned high score. Anything which you can buy in the shop you can get in the game without paying a cent. you can earn and get runies in the game , sure its slower but its not a game you play overnight or in a week or even a month. its a long term game that you can play and enjoy for years , improving and building your city. its a thinking game where you plan things and as you grow you have to move things around and keep supply and usage in ballance. there are lots of quests that will teach you and lead you through the game.

in closing its by far one of (if not) the best FREE online browser game around. i have played many many over the years. its not a new game but is still being updated some people have been playing it since at least 2013

All the negative reviews are from those that don't want to understand the game as its not their style of game thats fine, however there are lots of people out there that are expecting it to be the next great slice of heaven, and have pvp (which it doesn't) and thats the beauty of it the community helps players. theres trading goods on the auction house

All free" games have to make money somehow and walking that fine line between being frustrating enough to make you buy things and so frustrating you quit playing is the difference between success and failure. date:

Pros: the graphics are beautiful; the software doesn't crash; the chat and moderators are helpful and the first city on the first island is a lot of fun.

reviewText:
I thought I'd try the game for a while.
Upon release I already got tempted to play but never did. But I tried now.
For nearly 11 hours I played this game. I'm at 2k population now with a couple of colonists and I thoroughly enjoy it.
It might still be a little early for me to review, but it's a positive one for sure.
Beyond any expectations it immediately hooked me to the game after the first 15 minutes.

Now, regarding micro transactions, I got tempted quite a few times already..
I'm not sure whether I will buy gems or not. For now gem production seems to go fairly quickly.
Everything is achievable without having to lay down real money for it.
It's too early for me to say whether this is full F2P or only partially.

The graphics are not too special, nor is the combat. But it's a (steam ported?) browser game.
It only requires a couple of MB to play and it needs flash, which is a pity. But hey, it works, and it looks okay.
I also completely love the music. Really good job at that. It makes the game that much more immersive.
Especially the female solo vocal. Wow!

This review will probably be updated later on with a bit more in-depth arguments on why I like playing this game.
As of now : It just got me interested and I'd like to see my city grow =3

I'd give this an 8/10.

Cheers,
Nemesis Theory
